Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - Apart from the number of opioid pills per person, there are probably many other socioeconomic factors that need to be considered when looking into the number of opioid overdoses in West Virginia. For example, the number of opioid overdoses could be related to the fact that each year, people are becoming more stressed due to other societal factors, such as unemployment.
Q15.2_5: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#1330). The year with the fewest number of people was 2002-2003 with an estimated 330 victims.
Q16.2_1: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#3110). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - This is a scatter plot entitled “Old Faithful Eruptions” that plots Waiting Time Between Eruptions (Min) by Eruption Duration (Min). The Waiting Time Between Eruptions is plotted on the vertical y-axis from 50 to 90 with an increment of 10 minutes. The Eruption Duration is plotted on the horizontal x-axis from 1.5 to 5.0 with an increment of 0.5 minutes.
Q16.2_2: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#3110). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - Many Old Faithful eruptions last from 4.0 to 5.0 minutes and the waiting time between them is 70 to 90 minutes. Also, many eruptions last from 1.5 to 2.5 minutes and the waiting time between them is 50 to 60 minutes.
Q16.2_3: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#3110). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - Generally, the longer the waiting time between Old Faithful eruptions the longer that eruption will last. There are many very short eruptions with very short waiting time, and there are many very long eruptions with very long waiting time, but there are not many eruptions in-between (i.e., eruptions lasting around 3 minutes, with a waiting time of 70 minutes). Most eruptions either have a waiting time around 50 minutes or 80 minutes, and have a duration around 2.0 or 4.5 minutes, respectively.
Q16.2_4: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#3110). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - When Old Faithful eruptions have a short duration, it tends to be because the waiting time between them was short. This suggests that longer eruptions are due to a build-up of pressure in the geyser over time. Thus, the longer the waiting time between eruptions, the longer the eruption.
Q16.2_5: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#3110). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - The higher your MCAT and GPA are, the more likely you are to be accepted to Columbia University Medical School.
Q17.2_1: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#1212). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - This is a vertical bar chart entitled “Percent births delivered by C-Section by income in 2006/2007”. The percent of births delivered by C-section is plotted on the vertical y-axis from 0 to 25. The income categories are plotted on the horizontal x-axis for the following categories: Poorest, Poorer, Middle, Richer, and Richest.
Q17.2_2: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#1212). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - The Richest have the highest percent of births by C-section (31.7%). The Poorest have the lowest percent of births by C-section (4.1%). The Richest are almost twice as likely to have a baby delivered by C-section than the Richer and 3x more likely than the Middle.
Q17.2_3: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#1212). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - Overall, the richer you are the more likely you are to have a baby delivered by C-section in 2006/2007. There is an exponential rise in babies delivered by C-section as you move up the income ladder in 2006/2007. There is a discrepancy of around 27% between the Poorest and the Richest people, and a nearly-doubled increased percentage of births delivered by C-section between the Richer and the Richest people.
Q17.2_4: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#1212). Please rank each of the five textual descriptions below from least useful (1) to most useful (5). - The clear trend for the Richest people to have births delivered by C-section suggests that income is a huge factor in determining whether births are delivered by C-section or not. This may link to the possibility for the Richest people to access and afford a better and top quality health system. The Poorest people have the lowest percentage of C-sections, likely because they couldn't afford it, or because they were treated differently. This suggests there is a poverty gap in access to and education in birthing choices and healthcare.
Q17.2_5: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#1212). Q18.2_3: Here are the five textual descriptions for Ranking Task (#2122). Q1.4: I have read the above information. I agree to participate in this study.

Q73: I encounter inaccessible visualizations in all of these contexts
Q74: Work documents like memos, fliers, etc.
Q79: Presented as a standalone description, separate from the main text of the article.
Q80: It all depends on context.  I generally want to know what type of graphical info it is, graph, chart, picture of text, etc.  If the data represented is smaller, I like to know the actual data of the graphical information, or at least the highest, lowest, maybe average, and any abnormal trends.  For large amounts of data, like data for all 50 states, a summary is preferable, that covers the overall content.  I want to know about the data though, and not speculation on why this data is the way it is, unless it ties into the theme or context of the article.
Q81: If I need to organize a lot of data, I often use tables if it makes sense.  Tables are pretty easy to read using a screen reader, and it can be a great way to move through large amouts of data, especially if row and column headers are used properly.  I don't deal with charts and graphs too much, but bar and line graphs typically make the most sense to me.  Pie charts are also pretty easy to understand.  I don't use scatter plots and similar charts much.
Q82: This was an interesting survey, especially with the number and variety of scenarios given.  I tended to want to know a combination of each questions's elements, and ones that did a good job of straight up representing or summarizing the data.  I didn't care as much for the speculation text options that seemed to tell you how to think, rather than more neutrally representing the data.    Also in the Births by C Section question, there was supposed to be a link in the question, like other questions, but the This Link in that question was just plain text.  Because of this, I ranked the description of the information highest, then the data, since I didn't have the actual tabular data to go by had the link actually been a link.

Q80: I find the raw data to be the most useful. Any assumptions or corelations made prior to me knowing the data feel like a bias even though they may not be as such. I prefer to come to these conclusions on my own rather than have them spelled out.
Q81: Many times I find that these "visualizations" are nothing more than the conclusions the author has drawn from the data rather than a description of the visualization itself. That's if there even is an accessible way to access the data in the first place.

Q80: I noticed some of these descriptions were "opinions." For instance: People living in low-income countries tend to have a lower life expectancy than the people living in high-income countries. This is likely due to many societal factors, including access to healthcare, food, other resources, and overall quality of life. People who live in lower income countries are more likely to experience deprivation and poverty. They are more likely to have poor working and living conditions and can develop related health problems. None of this has anything to do with the actual graph, etc. This is a study, so obviously you include stuff like this, but for "real" descriptions, this sort of thing should absolutely be avoided. I liked most of the descriptions, actually, if they were "combined." For instance, some of the descriptions (I mostly rated as 4) only mentioned the title and labels of the axes. If combined with the 1s or 2s, that'd make for a great description.
Q81: I sometimes encounter them on news sites, etc, but mostly on Twitter, Facebook, etc, and on bank statements, etc, which I need sighted help to read. Q82: I really like this study. I like the interest in visual descriptions. Some of the "wrong" ones were amusing (is the Netflix, Walmart, etc ones actually real?)

Q79: Presented as a standalone description, separate from the main text of the article.
Q80: A most useful description contains the data from the visualization, without opining or interpretation by the describer. If there are too many data points to convey individually, the description needs to contain all of the variations, no matter how minute, to be accurate. If a visualization is large and complex, it's ok for the description to be very long and complex. If the visualization is widely scattered, it's ok for its description to be widely scattered.
Q81: I am totally blind, and virtually all data visualizations I encounter are undescribed, and as such are unavailable. This has been acutely made clear on Twitter and in newspapers around the COVID-19 pandemic and the recent U.S. election. Often, visualizations are presented with very little introduction or coinciding text. I feel very left out of the world and left out of the ability to confidently traverse that world. The more data I am unable to access, the more vulnerable and devalued I feel.
Q82: I very much appreciate the time and effort put into this well-designed study by the researchers. I struggled to manage the sets of five possible descriptions to rank, and would be intrigued to see whether a study with only four items to rank would net similar findings.

Q80: I think the description should be brief, but should still convey enough information for a totally blind reader to understand the visualization, based on the article's context. This is why I'd find shorter descriptions more useful. You do not want the visualization description to be too long and verbose, thus taking away from the article. This is just my personal preference, however. Others will probably prefer different methods.

Q80: An illustrative description which says waht is sow on which axis, teh style of the diagram, colours used, if effect sizes are indicated by shading etc only if the data is available. it is helpful to have this kind of descripton if i wantto discuss teh visualisation with a colleagues, but unless I have the numbers this understadning is of no help. I don't want a descriptin to by analytical and to to inlcude text about the possible causes of what the visualisaton shows. That should be seperate. I want to have teh time and space to interpret the numbers for myself before I read teh analysis. what I want alos depends on the context in which the visualisation is shown. if it is to illustrate a sinlge point from a set of data "this shows that" then the descripton should reflect that purpose. HOwever, if teh visualisation is there to show a more complex story then I would rather a description which is longer and inlcudes a range of details, including numbers, ranges, changes etc.
Q81: I often encounter inaccessible data visualisations in news articles or on social media.  IN the main this is not a big problem because it is clear from the article, post etc what the message is that they are being used in support of. I would prefer to have the visualisaton but I don't need it to get the point. It is more of an issue when I come across visualisations in published reports, management informaton at work etc where there is not a single message which can be captured in the narrative, or where the purpose of the visualisation is to allow the reader to focus on the point which is most relevent to them e.g. people may be interest in teh data for their geographical area, year of birth etc.
Q82: the type of descriptions which explain what the visualiasaton looks like rather than what it is showing are most useful when the data is also available in a table or spreadsheet. I often come across visuallisaton accompanied by a dataset but if the data is presented with lots of use of colour, of white space for layout etc it is very difficult for me to build up a mental picture of the data set before I start to find my way around it to find the numbers I am interested in. for these a description such as "this is a table listing countries down the lefthand column. Across the top of the table are years from 1900 to 2000. Belwo each year thre are 3 columns of number, male, female, and total. number for males are in columns 2, 5, 8 etc, for female in 3, 6, 9 etc. and total number for each country in each year in column 4, 7, 10 etc.

Q82: Throughout this study I have found I lean more toward hard facts, outright dismiss a mere description of what the data graph/chart/whatever looks like and prefer to leave any presumptious commentary such as it can be presumed in richer countries... etc. Some vaugeness can be nice but I tend to want hard facts and numbers rather than a general idea. I think my choices have reflected that except in my first choice perhaps. Q80: Numerical data should be pesented without editorial interpretation. (Unless there are just TOO MANY NUMBERS! I.e., descriptions should focus on min/max values, intersection points.) Also, knowing which numbers are important can depend on the context given by the article (or other surrounding text). Sometimes knowing the type of chart is useful, but less so than the numbers presented.
Q81: I think you have correctly identified the main sources as social media, news sites, government sites. Of these I suppose it's most important for official government info to be accurate. Sadly, none of the three categories provides consistently accurate DV descriptions. As a screen reader user, I generally end up skipping the visuals & trying to find the info in other forms (from text of acccompanying article, etc.) AI attempting to convert these images is still in its infancy (Facebook & Apple auto descriptions of general images are more of a timewaster than useful.) As a practical matter, if I find an inaccessible chart / graph, I just move on. Can we have a graph of % of charts that are accessible over time?... #hahaa
Q82: I don't know what question formats are available to you, but the radio button version is pretty difficult to deal with using a screen reader. It's hard to get an overview of which choices I have already selected. Just having edit boxes to type "1", "2", "3", "4", "5" would be easier. ... The "reordering" options showing up in iOS (Language pref settings & other places) might be a good way to go in future. (With each option there is a choice to "Move Up, or "Move Down", which changes the ranking of the various items.) Just a thought....

Q73: Educational materials such as textbooks, audiobooks, etc.
Q79: Presented as a standalone description, separate from the main text of the article.
Q80: I think a textual description is more useful if it contains the summary of the overall trends and distributions of the data rather than just mentioning some of the extreme values or means.   And it would be better if the description provides some deeper analysis like aligning data developments with the background of different time periods.  The description would be almost useless if it only describes the encoding of the visualization because the reader wouldn't get any insight from these texts, which not only increases the readers' reading burden but also conveys no effective information about the data.
Q81: Yes, I think there is a considerable barrier to understand visualizations when I'm dealing with some large visual analysis systems, which often use very complex visual encodings and involve many ways of interaction. Although these systems may be easy to use and explore for some skilled data analysts, they can cause great confusion to ordinary users. Since it would usually take a long time to figure out where the analyzing flow should start and how the visualizations are coordinated. Even with well-organized multi-view visualization generated by analysts using these systems, it would still be hard for users to interpret.
Q82: This is a very interesting survey and I expect a lot from it. However, the real situation is a lot more complicated than the authors set in the survey. For example, the visualization may not be totally inaccessible, there may be just some limited number of dead pixels on the materials (newspaper, screen, and others), and some part of the visualization could still be seen. As for the textual description, there must be an appropriate length for that. Some of the descriptions in the survey are too long and contained too many details. Although the descriptions can be very thorough in this way, it really heavys the reading burden when the visualization is actually accessible, which is the most case for me.  Technically, I think it points to a bigger problem of using multiple media (visualization and natural language) to help people better understand the underlying data, especially when some parts of the visual or textual descriptions are inaccessible. Combining the advantages of both vision and language, it will guide the users to find out more about the data. I think there are a lot of opportunities for that.

Q73: I encounter inaccessible visualizations in all of these contexts
Q79: Presented both as a standalone description and presented in the main text of the article.
Q80: A textual description of a visualization is more useful when it provides a succinct and objective summary of the information. Descriptions become less useful when subjective opinions are included or when the description attempts to comprehend the data for the reader.
Q81: The largest barriers that I experience with regard to lack of accessibility to data visualizations has to do with interpreting reports that can be generated to indicate library related tasks, e.g checkouts, holds, purchases, etc. Although these reports can be generated as spreadsheets, depending on comprehensiveness of the report, it often takes more work for a screen reader to interpret the data.
Q82: The biggest barrier that I see with regard to accessible data visualization is the amount of work necessary to create a textual description without trying to interpret the data for the user. Until AI technologies are able to efficiently generate these types of descriptions, scalability will continue to remain a barrier to access.
